item.title: Capcom Next: Summer 2024 set for July 1
Donkey Kong Country Returns HD Preorders Are Live
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/donkey-kong-country-returns-hd-preorder-nintendo-switch/1100-6524388/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Donkey Kong Country Returns is, er, returning once again with a new, refreshed HD port on the Nintendo Switch. Donkey Kong Country Returns originally released on Wii in 2010 and was then ported to Nintendo 3DS in 2013. Now, over a decade later, DK and Diddy are swinging back into action with remastered graphics and everything offered in both previous versions of the side-scrolling platformer. Donkey Kong Country Returns HD is available to preorder now ahead of its January 16, 2025 release date.

Essentially presented as the "definitive" edition of the wonderful platformer, Donkey Kong Country Returns HD will offer the original challenge of the Wii version while also giving players the option to play with the friendlier 3DS settings. It also contains all of the extra levels from the 3DS version. Players can take on the 80-level, nine-world gauntlet as Donkey Kong and Diddy Kong in either solo or two-player co-op modes.

Donkey Kong Country Returns HD Preorder Bonuses

Nintendo rarely offers preorder bonus for its first-party titles, and Donkey Kong Country Returns HD is no different. However, if something is announced, we'll be sure to update.

Donkey Kong Country Returns HD is a great opportunity for fans to revisit the 2D platformer with sharper visuals and new controls, or for newcomers to try out for the first time. However, don't skip out on Donkey Kong Country Returns: Tropical Freeze HD either. Both games rank among the best 2D platformers ever made, and Tropical Freeze HD is a great way to pass the time while waiting for the new release. You can grab a physical copy of Tropical Freeze from Walmart for $48.

It's worth noting that the original versions of Returns and Tropical Freeze were made by Retro Studios, who is also responsible for the upcoming 2025 game Metroid Prime 4: Beyond. While we're still waiting for Prime 4 preorders--they were available at Amazon and Walmart but are no longer being sold--you can grab the studio's latest available release, Metroid Prime Remastered, for a few bucks off at Walmart.

Donkey Kong Country Returns HD is one of four upcoming Switch exclusives that debuted in the Nintendo Direct and is available to preorder now:

  • The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Mario & Luigi: Brothership -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Super Mario Party Jamboree -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns HD -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop

item.title: Super Mario Party Jamboree For Nintendo Switch Is Available To Preorder Now
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/super-mario-party-jamboree-preorder-nintendo-switch/1100-6524363/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Super Mario Party Jamboree, the latest entry in the long-running party game series, was shown off during the latest Nintendo Direct. When it launches on October 17, it'll be the third iteration of Mario Party on Nintendo Switch. Nintendo is calling Jamboree the biggest Mario Party, as it will include over 110 minigames. Preorders for Super Mario Party Jamboree are live now at major retailers.

Jamboree is following up 2021's Mario Party Superstars and the 2018 hit Super Mario Party. If you don't already own those games, you can hone your skills ahead of Jamboree's release by picking up Superstars for $50 at Walmart and Super Mario Party either on its own for $50 or bundled with a pair of red and blue Joy-Con controllers for $99. Considering Mario Party games can be played with single Joy-Con controllers, this bundle is a convenient way to add two more players to the party.

Super Mario Party Jamboree Preorder Bonuses

Though Nintendo typically doesn't offer preorder bonuses for its games, major retailers are known to give away little Nintendo trinkets. Nothing has been announced on that front just yet, but we'll update this preorder guide if and when we hear more.

Super Mario Party Jamboree looks to be a nice step forward for the iconic series, offering more mini-games, five new maps, and a handful of returning maps from previous entries. Along with the traditional Mario Party experience of racing around a board and battling against friends, you can now jump online to challenge 19 other players in the new Koopathlon mode.

It sounds like there are even more new modes players will get to explore--but Nintendo is keeping them under wraps. Expect to hear more about Super Mario Party Jamboree as we get closer to its release on October 17.

Plenty of other games were highlighted during the latest Nintendo Direct, including The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom, Mario & Luigi Brothership, and Donkey Kong Country Returns HD. We also got a long-awaited look at Metroid Prime 4, which not only exists, but is slated for a 2025 launch.

Below, we've rounded up the Nintendo Switch exclusives from the Direct that are now available to preorder.

  • The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Mario & Luigi: Brothership -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Super Mario Party Jamboree -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns HD -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop

Read the full preorder guides:

  • The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom preorder guide | Release Date: September 26
  • Mario & Luigi: Bowsership preorder guide | Release Date: November 7
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns preorder guide | Release Date: January 16

item.title: Mario & Luigi: Brothership Is Up For Preorder - The Mario Bros. RPG Series Returns This November
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/mario-and-luigi-brothership-preorder-nintendo-switch/1100-6524356/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Mario & Luigi: Brothership arrives on November 7, and preorders are now open for the upcoming RPG. It's reveal was a big surprise during the latest Nintendo Direct, especially considering the series' original developer, AlphaDream, went bankrupt in 2019. But on the heels of modernized versions of Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door and Super Mario RPG, Nintendo is resurrecting the Mario & Luigi series with a brand-new entry. Mario & Luigi: Brothership preorders are starting to go live ahead of its release this holiday. Brothership marks not only return of the Mario Bros. role-playing series, it's also the first entry in the series for a home console--though you could play it entirely on a portable device, of course.

Mario & Luigi: Brothership Preorder Bonuses

No preorder bonuses have been announced for Mario & Luigi: Brothership, though that could change in the coming weeks and months. Nintendo games rarely have official bonuses, but major retailers often offer exclusive collectibles while supplies last.

Aside from two 3DS remakes, the last entirely new entry in the Mario & Luigi series, Paper Jam, arrived in 2015. That means fans have waited nearly 10 years for more turn-based, platforming action--and Brothership's reveal trailer makes it clear that Nintendo is embracing the legacy of the Mario & Luigi RPG series. It has cool graphics that retain the aesthetic and perspective of previous entries, a turn-based combat system with Action Commands (timing-based maneuvers) and new Bros. Attacks, and an emphasis on platforming and puzzles outside of battles.

We also met a few new characters, including the Extension Corps, Snoutlet, and Connie. Of course, Bowser also makes an appearance, though aside from guiding Mario and Luigi across a series of unique islands, it's unclear how the story will unravel. Expect to learn more as we close in on its November release date.

If you haven't played Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door and Super Mario RPG yet, these recently released Switch games will give you a pretty good idea of the combat system in traditional RPGs set in the Mushroom Kingdom. You can save on Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door at Walmart, while Super Mario RPG is cheap at Amazon and Walmart ($33).

Mario & Luigi: Brothership isn't the only Nintendo-published Switch game from the Nintendo Direct that's available to preorder now. You can also preorder the new Zelda game, the latest Mario Party, and the remastered version of Donkey Kong Country Returns. Here's a handy list of where to preorder these highly anticipated Nintendo games:

  • The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Mario & Luigi: Brothership -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Super Mario Party Jamboree -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns HD -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop

item.title: The Legend Of Zelda: Echoes Of Wisdom Preorders Are Live Now
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-legend-of-zelda-echoes-of-wisdom-preorder-nintendo-switch/1100-6524359/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom was revealed during the latest Nintendo Direct, and it'll offer a long-awaited twist on the usual formula: a role reversal for Link and Zelda. Link is one of the many Hyrulians who find themselves pulled into a mysterious rift, which means it's Princess Zelda's turn to save the day. Echoes of Wisdom--a title that nods to Zelda's ownership of the Triforce of Wisdom--makes use of the same vibrant visual style seen in the Switch version of Link's Awakening, and it appears to offer a sprawling world for players to explore from a top-down perspective. The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom releases on September 26, and preorders are now open ahead of its launch in a few short months.

Alongside Echoes of Wisdom, Nintendo is launching a new Zelda-themed Nintendo Switch Lite console. The limited-edition console isn't available to preorder just yet, but we'll update this guide as soon as it's live at major retailers. If you aren't able to get the Zelda-themed Switch Lite but still need a Switch, we'd recommend checking out the Animal Crossing-themed model at Walmart. This turquoise Switch Lite bundle is $199 and comes with a digital copy of Animal Crossing: New Horizons.

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom Preorder Bonuses

Nintendo rarely offers preorder bonuses for its games, though it's fairly common for major retailers to get exclusive physical goodies that serve as neat bonuses. Other Zelda games on Switch came bundled with little trinkets at select retailer. We'll update our Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom preorder guide if bonuses become available at major retailers.

To coincide with the game's release, Nintendo is launching a Hyrule Edition Nintendo Switch Lite. It features a golden color scheme with black accents, along with a Hylian Crest on the back. It's a good-looking gadget, but if you want to get your hands on it before it sells out, consider reserving a unit as soon as you can.

The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom is a throwback to pre-Breath of the Wild Zelda that retains the colorful visuals of Link's Awakening. Unlike Link, Zelda doesn't wield a trusty sword; she uses a newly acquired power called Echoe, which lets her create items that help you traverse Hyrule, overcome enemies, and solve puzzles. Echoes allow you to replicate NPCs who will then fight on your behalf or help you solve puzzles.

Based on the reveal trailer, the new mechanics could add a lot of variance to each playthrough. Nintendo even stated players will have different experiences based on how they approach using Echoes. In this way, Echoes of Wisdom is similar to Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom, especially the latter, which implemented a robust building tool called Ultrahand that encouraged players to experiment to solve puzzles, explore the world, and defeat enemies. Though Echoes of Wisdom, as a top-down Zelda game, clearly won't be as dynamic, it's cool to see the melding of classic Zelda with the modern approach to the franchise. And it's even cooler to see Zelda step into the leading role for the first time. Well, for the first time on a Nintendo platform at least. Zelda's Adventure for Philips CD-i does indeed exist.

If you're not all caught up on the major The Legend of Zelda games on Switch, you can save on the other four mainline games that have received physical editions at Walmart right now. Link's Awakening would be a good one to play before Echoes of Wisdom since it shares the same foundation.

  • The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild -- $43 ($60)
  • The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom -- $51 ($70)
  • The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening -- $40 ($60)
  • The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword HD -- $40 ($60)

Here are all of the Nintendo-published games from June's Nintendo Direct that you can preorder now:

  • The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Mario & Luigi: Brothership -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Super Mario Party Jamboree -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop
  • Donkey Kong Country Returns HD -- $60
    • Best Buy
    • GameStop

Read the full preorder guides:

item.title: SteamWorld Heist 2 Unannounced for Game Pass, PR Says Logo Was a Mistake
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/steamworld-heist-2-unannounced-for-game-pass-pr-says-logo-was-a-a-mistake

On track to launch without Game Pass this August.

SteamWorld Heist 2 is no longer confirmed for a Game Pass launch despite previous messaging from developer Thunderful.

When the studio originally revealed its steampunk strategy follow-up in April of this year, it promised fans that they would see it launch on August 8, 2024, for PC, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X | S, and Game Pass. However, as spotted by XboxEra, social media posts mentioning a Game Pass release have since been deleted, and trailers that included the Xbox serviceâs branding have seemingly been modified and reuploaded without the logo. Its inclusion can still be seen in re-uploads from third-party accounts like YouTube channel GN Game Trailers.

A representative with Fortyseven PR confirmed with XboxEra that SteamWorld Heist 2 is no longer coming to Game Pass, adding that the Xbox service's logo was mistakenly added. Thunderful and Fortyseven did not reveal how the Game Pass logo managed to worm its way into an official trailer, but in a statement sent to Kotaku's Ethan Gach, a spokesperson further clarified that distribution plans for SteamWorld Heist 2 are still being ironed out.

"We inadvertently included a Game Pass logo in our reveal trailer," the statement says. "We have not finalized our distribution plans for SteamWorld Heist 2 at this time. We'll share news about our distribution plans closer to launch."

SteamWorld Heist 2 is still planned to launch for all other previously announced console and PC platforms. The sequel follows Captain Leeway and their struggle against a new menace that threatens the Great Sea. Spicing up the turn-based combat this time around is real-time naval combat, more crew customization, more story, and more steampunk weapons.

Steamworld Heist 2 - Announcement Screenshots

Although it's looking like SteamWorld Heist 2 wonât sneak its way into Game Pass when it launches this August, the service does currently offer other SteamWorld games to enjoy. Included in the PC and console tiers today are SteamWorld Dig 2 and SteamWorld Build. Console players also have access to the original SteamWorld Dig. We interviewed the team at Thunderful about SteamWorld Heist 2 when it was revealed earlier this year. During our chat, we learned more about how the team keeps the SteamWorld franchise chugging with each new release as well as how the sequel gives tactical players more to explore.

Michael Cripe is a freelance contributor with IGN. He started writing in the industry in 2017 and is best known for his work at outlets such as The Pitch, The Escapist, OnlySP, and Gameranx.

Be sure to give him a follow on Twitter @MikeCripe.

item.title: Steam launches new background gameplay recording and sharing feature into beta
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/steam-launches-new-background-gameplay-recording-and-sharing-feature-into-beta

Along with Replay mode and more.

Valve is expanding Steam's already teetering tower of built-in features with a new background gameplay recording and sharing system that's available in beta now.

As detailed on Valve's Game Recording beta page, Steam's new suite of console-like video features begin with two distinct recording modes. A Background Recording mode continuously saves gameplay to a preferred drive - users can set duration and storage limits - while an On Demand Recording mode enables users to start and stop recording as they choose.

A new timeline feature and player-added event markers are intended to make it easier to find key moments (achievements, screenshots, and in-game events in supported games can also auto-generate markers if desired) and recordings can be clipped using new "lightweight" tools.

There's also a redesigned Recordings & Screenshots interface where users can edit and share footage, and a one-click sharing option for posting video into a chat session with a friend or to the world at large. Valve says recordings can easily be transferred to another device - Steam Deck to PC, for instance - and temporary links to MP4s can be sent via the Steam Mobile App or a QR code.

And finally, a new Replay mode is accessible from the Steam Overlay in every game, enabling users to quickly jump back through their recent gameplay. "Useful for things like seeing what went wrong when your hero died," Valve notes, "or recalling something mentioned by an NPC earlier."

Steam's new Game Recording system - detailed more thoroughly here - is currently available in beta for all users, and developers can access a new SDK and API. To explore the new features, Steam users should go into Settings > Interface > Beta Participation then select either Beta option. Background or On Demand recording can then be enabled via Settings > Game Recording. Expect a public release after Valve has ironed out any kinks.

item.title: You will never guess Wordleâs terrible, hilarious original name
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/24186786/wordle-original-name-mr-bugs-wordy-nugz-wardle

Wordle is a pretty clever name for the very good word game created by Josh Wardle. But when he was first working on it in 2013, Wardle had another name in mind that isnât quite as catchy.

âThis is true: I was going to call Wordle, Mr. Bugsâ Wordy Nugz,â Wardle revealed as part of a presentation about Wordle at Figmaâs Config conference on Wednesday. He also showed a slide that spelled out the name in big yellow letters. âHad I called the game Mr. Bugs, I like to think it would not have been successful.â

During the presentation, which was about the development decisions that he said âare the opposite of what youâre meant to doâ but ultimately contributed to making the game a hit, Wardle also discussed the history of the game and showed off a bunch of early prototypes. Wardle had wanted to make a game for his partner. He liked words and liked the game Mastermind, so in 2013, he mashed the two ideas together and started making what would become Wordle.

His first prototype was for Android, and much of the core game was there: you had six guesses to figure out a five-letter word. But this early version was an endless game, meaning that as soon as you figured out one word, you could try and solve another. It also picked from five-letter words at random, meaning you might have been trying to figure out more obscure words like âzizelâ or âyrneh.â

Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge

In order to whittle down the word list to a set of words that âpeople could reasonably know,â Wardle then built another game where you could press a button to say if you knew a word, didnât know it, or maybe knew it. This helped him winnow the list down from 13,000 to about 2,500 words.

Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge

He also kept working on the gameâs design. In some older iterations he included with his presentation, the game had things like a score or red X marks to denote âlives.â

Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge

Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge

This all happened in 2013, when he was also considering the Mr. Bugs name. But then, Wardle said he lost interest in the game, âput it on the back burner,â and didnât touch it for six years.

In early 2020, Wardle and his partner were playing a lot of The New York Timesâ crossword and its Spelling Bee game. He noticed that they were both once-a-day kind of games â there is only one Spelling Bee a day, and the dayâs crossword must be completed on the same day in order to maintain a streak. He decided to make a similar choice for what would become Wordle.

In 2021, he built a version of what would become Wordle that lived on his personal domain (which is where you might have played Wordle before The New York Times fully took it over).

âThis was something else I did that youâre not meant to do. I made a website,â Wardle said. âI think a lot of the thinking around games was that you want apps so you can catch your audience. You can send them push notifications. I didnât want to do any of that. It was just [my partner] and I playing the game. So making a website seemed so obvious to me.â He thinks being a website helped the game, as you could just share it with someone and they could play it.

Screenshot by Jay Peters / The Verge

For about six months, Wardle said it was just the two of them playing the game on his website. Then, he shared it with family, they shared it with friends, and it started to grow from there. After seeing people post their results in emoji form, he formally added emoji results as a feature to the game in late 2021.

On January 31st, The New York Times announced that it had bought Wordle from Wardle. âI think this took a lot of people by surprise,â Wardle said in his presentation. âIt was a very clear decision for me to make to sell the game. I didnât want to run a games business. Iâm interested in creating things.

âIt was obvious due to the success of Wordle that I could make my life if I wanted to,â Wardle continued. âBut there are a bunch of things that I wouldnât enjoy about running a games business. And it just felt so clear to me that that wasnât something I wanted any part of.â

He also said that he didnât want to monetize the game. âAll of this comes back to [that] Iâm building the game for my partner. Iâm not going to show her ads or try and upsell her on a premium subscription. But itâs even though I didnât want to make money from Wordle, it quickly became apparent to me that there were other people who were going to make money off Wordle, whether I was involved or not.â Wardle said that âselling to The New York Times was a way to just to step away.â

Wardle concluded by saying that, if he had wanted to make a viral word game, he wouldnât have made Wordle. âI was trying to do something that was authentic to me. I was trying to build something for someone that I loved. It just so happened a bunch of other people loved it.â

His advice for other people trying to make things? âDonât try to make Wordle. Make the thing that youâre passionate about that is meaningful to you. And then everything else will follow from that.â

item.title: A New Official Steam Controller Is On The Way. Yes, For Real
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/a-new-official-steam-controller-is-on-the-way-yes-for-real/1100-6524544/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Controller manufacturer Hori has announced a new Steam-focused wireless controller launching later this year. Hori's wireless Steam controller is officially licensed by Valve, and both companies worked together to ensure the gamepad and all its features are fully compatible with Steam on desktop and Steam Deck.

Valve discontinued its own official Steam controller back in 2019, so this new collaboration with Hori is notable. As of now, it's the only controller for Steam that's in active production, which is pretty wild considering how massive Steam is.

Unlike the discontinued Steam controller, which used touch-based trackpads instead of thumbsticks and a unique button layout, Hori's pad offers a more traditional design similar to most other wireless controllers. All the expected face buttons, shoulder triggers, and thumbsticks are present, but there are also a few bonus features, including four remappable buttonsâtwo on the front and two paddles on the back. It also has dedicated buttons for the Steam Big Picture Mode overlay and Steam Quick Access Menu.

Hori's Steam controller uses offset thumbstick placement like the standard Xbox or Nintendo Switch Pro controllers. Unfortunately, the thumbsticks do not use anti-drift Hall Effect sensors, but they do have touch-sensitive stick tops like the Steam Deck's thumbsticks. It also lacks rumble support. However, there are plenty of other features, including turbo mode and gyro support.

As for connectivity, Hori's wireless Steam controller supports Steam Input over Bluetooth or wired USB, so it should work natively with Steam and Steamdeck. There's also an XInput mode so you can use the controller on Windows with non-Steam games, but that mode only works with wired connections and disables gyro controls. That said, Windows users can use Hori's desktop app to adjust settings like stick sensitivity, button mapping, and more. The controller has an estimated 12-hour battery life in Bluetooth mode.

Hori's wireless Steam controller launches on October 31. So far, it's only been announced for Japan. There's no word on if or when the controller will be available outside Japan, but for now, preorders are live at Hori's online store for Â¥7,980, or roughly $50 USD. It comes in white, black, neon yellow, and neon purple colors. We'll be sure to update if the controller becomes available in North America. Interestingly, there is an an Xbox (wired) controller from Hori that has a very similar design.

In the meantime, if you're looking for our recommendations for more gamepads that work with Steam, check out our list of the best controllers for PC.

Fighting game fans should also consider Hori's newly announced Street Fighter controller. Releasing in August and available to preorder from Amazon now, the Hori Fighting Commander Octa is offered in two different Street Fighter themes: Cammy and Juri. item.title: Someone Is Porting Super Mario 64 To The Game Boy Advance
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/sm64-super-mario-64-game-boy-advance-gba-port-gameplay-1851562711

A fan developer is doing something that seems impossible: Porting Super Mario 64 to the Game Boy Advance. And so far, their progress is impressive.

Suggested Reading

6 Things To Know Before Starting Persona 5 Tactica

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

Developed and published by Nintendo in 1996 for the N64, Super Mario 64 remains a milestone in video game history. Sure, itâs not the first 3D game ever developed, but it popularized many features and mechanics that continue to exist in modern games. It was groundbreaking and relied heavily on the then-newly released N64 and its advanced (for the time) hardware. And now this iconic platformer is being squeezed onto the far less powerful Game Boy Advance.

As spotted by NintendoLife, developer, and modder Joshua Barretto is rebuilding SM64 for the Game Boy Advance. Initially, Barretto had wanted to port the original N64 game to the GBA, but that proved unfeasible for a number of reasons. So instead, the modder is re-writing the game from scratch to run efficiently on a GBA. A recent video shows just how much progress the creator has made on the project.

This is pretty impressive on its own, but itâs even more amazing when you see how much progress Barretto has made in a short amount of time. Back in early May, the developer showcased a red triangle slowly moving around a vaguely SM64-like level. Now, Barretto has Mario hopping and running around a world that looks a lot more like Super Mario 64.

Even wilder is that, according to Barretto, this custom-built version of Super Mario 64 will be playable on a real GBA. In fact, there is already a video of someone toying around with an early build of Barrettoâs work on GBA hardware.

So whatâs next? Barretto wants to add more features from SM64 into this homebrew port. Eventually, the plan is to release this scratch-built port online, though it will lack any official Nintendo assets to avoid the publisherâs active lawyers. And then finally, we will be able to play Super Mario 64 on a GBA, something Iâve never wanted to do, but am excited to try one day.

item.title: This Ubisoft+ Deal Is Great If You Want Star Wars Outlaws And Assassin's Creed Shadows
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/this-ubisoft-deal-is-great-if-you-want-star-wars-outlaws-and-assassins-creed-shadows/1100-6524527/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Ubisoft has some big releases planned for later this year, with Star Wars Outlaws dropping on August 30 followed by Assassin's Creed Shadows on November 15. Picking up both will cost you $140 at minimum, and there's a good chance you'll have explored everything they have to offer by next summer, right? If that describes you, signing up for a one-year Ubisoft+ Premium membership could be a great alternative to buying the games outright. For a limited time, you can save $45 on an annual Ubisoft+ Premium membership, which drops the price from $180 to $135.

The discounted Ubisoft+ Premium annual membership is a limited-time offer that expires on July 11--so you've still got a bit of time to check out the service and see if it's a good fit. But if you plan on playing both Star Wars Outlaws and Assassin's Creed Shadows, it's an easy way to save five bucks while also granting access to all new Ubisoft games as well as a back catalog of just about every title from the publisher released in recent years (plus a bunch of classics). The Premium plan gets you day-one access to new releases, so you won't have to wait to play any of the big hits arriving this year.

Better yet, a Premium member unlocks the ultimate edition of both games, giving you tons of additional content to enjoy--including season passes and in-game cosmetics. You'll also get three-day early access to both games, allowing you to play Outlaws on August 27 and Shadows on November 15. Considering you'd spend $260 to get both Outlaws and Shadows ultimate editions, the value of this Ubisoft+ Premium subscription is pretty obvious. Even the standard editions cost $140 combined, though.

Along with Outlaws and Shadows, becoming a Ubisoft+ Premium member gets you access to a library of over 100 games from the Ubisoft catalog, such as Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown, Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora, Beyond Good and Evil's Anniversary Edition, and Far Cry 6, among dozens of others. You can see a full list of games here.

You'll also save 20% on any games you decide to purchase and earn exclusive monthly rewards. Signing up today means you'll have until next June to beat both games before canceling your membership (if you choose to do so).

Premium members can play on PC or Xbox, as well as through the cloud with Amazon's Luna game streaming service. Note that you'll need to cancel your membership before it automatically renews, as pricing will jump to its regular $180 per year once your discounted membership ends.

It's not quite as enticing as the above deal, but Ubisoft is also slashing the price of its Classics plan, which is now $60 (down from $80). It won't get you day one releases, but it does offer a catalog of 50 games, including Rainbow Six Extraction, Far Cry 6, and Immortals Fenyx Rising. This deal also expires on July 11, so swing by the Ubisoft Store and check out the offers while you can. Note that PlayStation users get Ubisoft+ Classic as part of their PlayStation Plus Extra subscription.

If you're not interested in Ubisoft+ or happen to be a PlayStation user who doesn't have access to the Ubisoft+ Premium offer, you can check out every edition of Assassin's Creed Shadows and Star Wars Outlaws that's available to preorder now. Collectors will want to pay attention to the retailer-exclusive preorder bonuses.

Star Wars Outlaws Preorders

Assassin's Creed Shadows Preorders

item.title: Mattel Committing to Board Game Accessibility Going Forward
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/mattel-committing-to-board-game-accessibility-going-forward

Mattel, the popular toy manufacturer, is investing further in board game accessibility. The company best known for Uno, Apples to Apples, and Blokus, has committed to making 80% of their games catalog colorblind-accessible by the end of 2024.

The Mattel Board Game Accessibility Commitment

According to a report by Polygon Mattel's investment in colorblind board game accessibility was announced on Tuesday. The inaugural run of accessible games will include versions of Uno, Tumblin' Monkeys, Phase-10, Ker Plunk, and Blokus. These versions will provide symbols associated with colors, tactile clues, and patterns.

Furthermore, Mattel will donate $30k worth of these colorblind-accessible games to summer camps across the United States through the YMCA.

Mattel's official store page provides additional context for this board game accessibility push. It cites a report by the Cleveland Clinic which states that 300 million people around the world have some form of colorblindness.

According to Mattel Vice President and Global Head of Games Ray Adler, the company partnered with several experts in the color deficiency field and consulted with colorblind individuals. This is consistent with the company's partnership with ColorADD to make colorblind Uno in 2017, as well as Uno Braille for the visually impaired in 2019.

Mattel plans to make 80% of their game catalog colorblind-accessible by the end of 2024. Moving forward, it expects 90% of its catalog will be colorblind-accessible by the end of 2025.

All future titles with this change will have a "colorblind accessible" symbol printed on the box. If you play mobile versions of Mattel's games through Mattel163 app, similar updates will be implemented.

Mattel's push for colorblind accessibility is part of similar movements in the tabletop industry. Back in 2022, Asmodee launched Access+, a studio dedicated to adapting board games for players with cognitive disabilities. Earlier this year, Paizo launched the All Ages label for their Pathfinder products, providing age-appropriate entertainment.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. Thisâ¦ More about Tyler

item.title: Enir-Ilim walkthrough in Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree
item.content:encoded:
https://www.polygon.com/elden-ring-shadow-erdtree-guide/24186341/enir-ilim-steps-sealing-tree-sote-dlc

Enir-Ilim is the final legacy dungeon in Elden Ringâs Shadow of the Erdtree DLC. Itâs located to the northwest of Belurat, but you wonât reach it until after defeating Romina, Saint of the Bud.

Our Elden Ring DLC guide shows a full walkthrough of the Enir-Ilim legacy dungeon and points you toward every site of grace, boss fight, and important item.

Enir-Ilim location

Youâll only reach Enir-Ilim after a lot of other work, since itâs technically the DLCâs final region. After defeating Messmer the Impaler in Shadow Keep, youâll need to head into the Rauh Ruins. There, at the Church of the Bud, youâll have to face Romina, Saint of the Bud. On the other side of her boss fight, youâll find the Sealing Tree. Buring it with Messmerâs Kindling will (finally) transport you to Enir-Ilim.

Inside Enir-Ilim, youâll have your final confrontation with Needle Knight Leda and then the DLCâs ultimate fight against Promised Consort Radahn.

Burn the Sealing Tree

Defeating Messmer the Impaler (and Base Serpent Messmer) will reward you with Messmerâs Kindling. Your next stop is the Church of the Bud in western Rauh Ruins. After defeating Romina, Saint of the Bud, youâll find the Sealing Tree behind her arena.

Approach the tree and choose to burn it. After a quick cutscene, youâll be transported to Enir-Ilim.

Reach the First Rise Site of Grace

When you arrive in Enir-Ilim, youâll be standing at the Enir-Ilim: Outer Wall Site of Grace (thereâs also a Somber Smithing Stone off to the west). Head up the stairs and around to the right.

At the top, a Divine Bird Warrior will come down the stairs on your left. Head up those stairs. Inside, loop around to the right and take the short stairs on your left to find the First Rise Site of Grace.

Reach the Spiral Rise Site of Grace

Take either of the curved staircases up to the level above you and then climb the stairs to find a Somber Smithing Stone and a dead end. Head back down to the site of grace.

Thereâs a straight hallway to the southeast with a Messmerfire Grease on the stairs. At the end, thereâs a lift that will take you down to Belurat â youâre on the other side of the branch-blocked path you found after defeating the Divine Beast Dancing Lion. Thereâs nothing for us to do here at the moment, so you donât actually have to take the elevator.

Instead, head to the west and up the stairs. Keep to the right and head inside the room. Clear the Shamans inside. Look in the back right corner past the tree root for a door. Head through, deal with the other Shaman, and grab the Rune Arc.

Drop off the ledge into the courtyard and clear out the Shamans and the Godskin-sized shaman who drops a Revered Spirit Ash. On the east side of the courtyard, take the stairs down.

On the landing below, youâll find a large tree surrounded by Man-Flies. Head along the roots to the west to find an altar room with another Revered Spirit Ash. Backtrack up to the fountain.

This time, go up the stairs heading east. Follow them around to the left. When you reach the top of that same large tree, head to the right. Drop off the ledge and onto the tree. Grab the Furlcalling Finger Remedy, and then follow the branches to the far side. Drop onto ledge and grab the Spira incantation.

Drop off the ledge and head back up the same stairs. Go past the tree and deal with the Divine Beast Warrior. At the first large landing, take out the really annoying caster and then keep to the right. Thereâs a small staircase leading down back the way you just came.

Head down, take a right, and grab the Inquisitor Ashes. Go back up to the main stairs and keep heading up.

Thereâs another shaman at the top of the stairs â above the door â who will ruin your day, so keep moving as you head up. Push through the doors to find the Spiral Rise Site of Grace, a Scadutree Fragment, and a Miquellaâs Cross.

Reach the Cleansing Chamber Anteroom Site of Grace

Head up the spiraling stairs to the open window on your left â where that jerk caster is. Jump out onto the roof and take a right.

Follow the roofs around and past the Gravebirds. Jump to the balcony at the far side, and take an immediate left into the room to find a Revered Spirit Ash.

Back outside, you have two options â follow the stairs up all the way to the next set or roofs, or take a quick detour â to end up in the same place. Just a little up the stairs, look for another staircase below you on the right. Jump the railing to drop onto them.

Head up those stairs and through the door to find the Horned Warrior Ashes and some Staunching Bolluses. Take a right and climb the ladder.

Head out onto the balcony to grab the Golden Horn Tender, and then climb the next ladder. Jump out onto the roofs ahead of you and deal with the Divine Beast Warrior waiting for you.

Take a left and head into the room at the top of the stairs â this is where the original stairs we jumped off end. Inside, youâll find a Scadutree Fragment. Head back out and continue across the roofs heading east.

Stick to the left, and youâll come to a corpse with a Sunwarmth Stone. Head back around to where you dropped out of the tower. Climb up the slanted roofs and into the window.

Take a left and climb the stairs to the top. Clear the Tree Shaman, and ride the lift down to the bottom. Follow the only path you can outside and deal with a Curseblade so you can pick up a Somber Ancient Dragon Smithing Stone. Back at the lift, face southwest and start it back up.

Thereâs a ledge ahead of you just a little ways up. Jump across to it and pick up the Gravebird Helm. Drop down, recall the lift, and ride it to the top.

Head outside and up the stairs. Cross the next landing and deal with the Divine Beast Warrior â this one carrying a Horned Warrior Greatsword. Continue past him and up the stairs.

Inside the next tower, youâll find the Cleansing Chamber Anteroom Site of Grace and a Scadutree Fragment.

Needle Knight Leda boss fight

Head east and up the stairs. Youâll come to a huge, sandy, open arena and Needle Knight Leda will start bad-mouthing you.

When she challenges you and leaves, check behind you before you hit her summon sign. There will be signs for Thiollier and Pureblood Knight Ansbach there. Summon them (to progress their respective questlines) and then hit the red sign to challenge Leda.

After you defeat Leda and her allies, youâll have a ton of loot to collect around the arena â every one will drop their armor set and weapons. When youâre done picking stuff up, continue east. When you hit the hall, Leda herself will be on your right for you to loot.

Go up the stairs to your left and ride the elevator to the top. Ansbach will be waiting for you at the top. Exhaust his dialogue, and then head up the stairs to the Divine Gate Front Staircase Site of Grace.

Elden Ring DLC final boss fight

All (âallâ) thatâs left is tackling Shadow of the Erdtreeâs final boss, Promised Consort Radahn.

Looking for more Shadow of the Erdtree guides? Check out our guides on new Elden Ring DLC weapons, armor, map fragments, sites of grace, and talismans. Weâve also got location guides on where to find Scadutree Fragments and Revered Spirit Ashes, and an interactive Elden Ring DLC map.

item.title: The Latest Acolyte Episode Is Star Wars At Its Most Sexy, Deadly
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/star-wars-acolyte-episode-5-qimir-master-review-1851562506

Star Wars is a lot of things, but it is rarely sexy. A few things spring to mind: Anakin Skywalkerâs bare chest after a nightmare, Padmeâs midriff in the fighting pit, or a sidelong glance from Han Solo, but in recent history the franchise has been somewhat devoid of sex and death. Kylo Ren and Rey Skywalker had some chemistry, sure, but it was akin to two teenagers first discovering horniness: clumsy, awkward, and at times, downright weird. And too many modern characters have been protected by plot armor, be it Boba Fett in his shitty Disney Plus series or side characters in The Mandalorian.

Suggested Reading

Fortnite Introduces Force Abilities In Latest Star Wars Collab

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

The latest episode of The Acolyte, titled The Master, is tailor-made for Star Warsâ adult audiences, giving us a sexy villain and a body count usually reserved for House of the Dragonâand it just so happened to be one of the strongest episodes of the franchise yet.

The first thing I notice about the strange, helmeted baddie that shows up to fight the Jedi in this episode are his arms. Theyâre bare, something we almost never see for Star Wars bad guys, and they are rippling with sweat-glistened muscles. As he takes on the small army of Jedi trying to protect Wookiee master Kelnocca, his biceps and triceps and forearms are on full display, moving with incredible, dangerous speed, like a cobra repeatedly coiling and striking.

The lightsaber battle he takes part in is one of the coolest Iâve ever seen in Star Wars. Itâs masterfully choreographed, with Dafne Keenâs Jecki and Lee-Jung Jaeâs Sol showing off some impressive skills as they face off against someone who doesnât follow the typical rules of engagement. We watch as they struggle to adapt to the strangerâs tactics, which include him using his helm to block and temporarily disable lightsabers. We see their faces change as they realize this is something the Jedi have never encountered, could not even fathom.

The Acolyte showrunners said they wanted to give us a lightsaber battle that would rival The Phantom Menaceâs Duel of the Fates, and boy, did they. Jecki is light on her feet and fast, leapfrogging off of objects to execute a stronger strike, while Solâs anger at the loss of so many of his kind slowly overtakes him, manifesting in the way he fights. By the time the opening half of the episode is over, there are cauterized holes gently emitting steam in almost all of the Jedi, including Keenâs Jecki, who dies quite terribly after knocking the helmet off the mystery man.

We watch him punch three holes through her with his newly split dual sabers, and as her body falls to the ground we get our big reveal: Itâs Manny Jacintoâs Qimir, his hair dripping with sweat and falling in pointed slices across his face, arms on full display, eyes full of rage. Evil has never looked this good.

And in case you werenât sure that Qimir, who has been secretly pretending to be a bumbling idiot and not the master controlling Mae (one of two roles for Amandla Stenberg), is evil, he soon after kills Yord (Charlie Barnett) in quite possibly the most gruesome manner ever seen in Star Wars. With Yord kneeling down in front of him, Qimir brutally snaps his neck. Yeah, he bad bad.

I watched nearly the entire episode with my mouth hanging open in shockâshock that The Acolyte would kill off two characters we were just getting to know, shock at how good the fights were, shock at the holes through bodies, the snapped neck, and the unparalleled, unapologetic sexiness of Jacinto. The Dark Side should tempt you, and thereâs no easier way to do that than by being hot as shit.

That the episode ends with what appears to be a few notes of Kylo Renâs theme as Qimir tenderly covers Oshaâs unconscious body with a shawl tells me two things: The Acolyte showrunners know that we yearn for sexy, murderous bad boys, and this series may tie into the movies more so than we expected. Is Qimir the first ever Knight of Ren, the acolytes of the Dark Side who rose to power when the Sith were considered extinct, whose name Kylo took as his own? It sure seems like it.

The next episode of The Acolyte airs on Tuesday July 2 on Disney Plus. I hope your air conditioning is working, because Iâm sure itâs gonna be another hot one.

.

item.title: Patent document showcases the cloud-only streaming Xbox console that never was
item.content:encoded:
https://arstechnica.com/?p=2033759

keystone revealed â

Microsoft couldn't get the price of its streaming Xbox low enough to release it.

Microsoft's mid-generation plans for the Xbox Series S and X consoles looked a whole lot different a couple of years ago than it does now. A leaked slide deck from the FTC v. Microsoft case last year outlined detailed plans for a spruced up Series S, an overhauled Series X, and even a redesigned controller. Another part of that roadmap included a streaming-only version of the Xbox, codenamed Keystone, that was designed to connect to Microsoft's Xbox Cloud Gaming servers rather than rendering games locally.

Microsoft has talked openly about this version of the Xbox before. Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer told The Verge that the Keystone console was designed and fully functional, but that it wasn't launched because Microsoft had a hard time getting the price down low enough that it made sense next to the $299 Series S (which already occasionally goes on sale in the $200 to $250 range).

We've already seen glimpses of the Keystone designâonce on Spencer's shelf, and again in the FTC v. Microsoft documents. Both of those depictions were partial, or seen from a distance. But a new design patent document (PDF) unearthed by Windows Central shows even more detailed renderings of what the cloud Xbox would have looked like.

Series S meets Apple TV

Keystone's styling was strongly reminiscent of the disc-drive-less Series S, with the same boxy white design and front-mounted Xbox button and USB port. There's also a similar circular cutout on top, though it may not be an air vent as it is in the Series Sâall of the holes depicted in the patent are on the back and bottom, and a streaming box certainly wouldn't have needed the same cooling capacity as the AMD-designed CPU and GPU in the Series S.

The console also would have been square-shaped and considerably smaller than a Series Sânot quite as small as a dedicated video-streaming box like an Apple TV or Roku Ultra, but not too far off either (the patent document doesn't list dimensions, but we've done a rough size comparison using the HDMI and Ethernet ports on the Keystone box and an Apple TV 4K). The console's controller sync button would have been mounted on its side, rather than in front, as it is on the Series S.

In the alternate reality of the FTC v. Microsoft slide deck, all of these new consoles and the new controller would have been announced or launched by now. But as Spencer said shortly after those documents leaked, the company's plans have changed substantially in the interim. A disc-less version of the Series X is coming, but it looks exactly like the current version of the console without a disc drive; Microsoft is also pursuing a strategy where it takes more of its internally developed games multi-platform rather than restricting them to the Xbox and to Windows PCs. These moves are at least partially in response to sliding revenue from Microsoft's console business, which has seen its revenue decline by double digits year over year for the last couple of years.

Neither Spencer nor Microsoft has ever said never about the Keystone console, leaving the door open to an eventual release if and when the price of manufacturing the console comes down. In the meantime, the streaming-only Xbox lives on as an app for newer Samsung smart TVs.

Listing image by Microsoft

Andrew Cunningham Andrew is a Senior Technology Reporter at Ars Technica, with a focus on consumer tech including computer hardware and in-depth reviews of operating systems like Windows and macOS. Andrew lives in Philadelphia and co-hosts a weekly book podcast called Overdue.

item.title: How To Save On Disney Epic Mickey: Rebrushed For PC
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-to-save-on-disney-epic-mickey-rebrushed-for-pc/1100-6524512/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

15 years after it first launched on the Nintendo Wii, Epic Mickey: Rebrushed is making a comeback on PC and consoles on September 24. Like most new games, the remake is priced at $60, but PC users can get a substantial discount through Fanatical. Right now, you can save 17% on your preorder with promo code FANATICAL17. This drops the price of your Steam key to $49.79. Thanks to the ongoing Red Hot Sale, if you preorder before July 11, you'll also get a free mystery gam or coupon for your next purchase

It's worth noting that Digital preorders come with 24-hour early access and a costume pack featuring Steam Boat Willie, Football, and Brave Little Tailor costumes.

The return of Epic Mickey is kind of a big deal, as video game legend Warren Spector's vision for a Disney game was a Wii exclusive. An imaginative romp through Disney's forgotten history, the game teamed Mickey up with Oswald Rabbit as they explored an alternate version of Disneyland that had been lost to the sands of time. Naturally, this new version will offer a massive visual leap forward when compared to the 480p graphics of the original Wii game.

Developer Purple Lamp is aiming to create a remake that will appeal to modern players, and while it looks like the core gameplay has been retained, there are updated controls as well. If you're looking to get the Epic Mickey: Rebrushed collector's edition, you'll sadly have a hard tim. Only 5,000 of these are being made, and they sold out quickly when listings went live.

You can check out our Epic Mickey: Rebrushed preorder guide for details on the standard versions available on console ahead of its release later this year.

While you're preordering your copy of Epic Mickey, you should also check out Fanatical's latest game bundles. Highlights include the Handheld Heroes bundle for Steam Deck and a Bethesda bundle that includes many of the publisher's best games for as low as $3 each. If you're feeling lucky, check out the Summer Mystery Bundle, which lets you get 20 random Steam games for $14.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: The Future of Black Desert Online: Everything from Heidel Ball 2024
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/the-future-of-black-desert-online/

It's been a while since I last wrote about Black Desert Online, and it's been even longer since I reviewed it in 2016. I have played it since then, but something always gets in the way, such as eating, sleeping, and bathing. However, I recently attended Heidel Ball 2024 as a guest of Pearl Abyss in Beynac-et-Cazenac, the inspiration of Heidel itself, and learned about what's coming. They're not slowing down.

With good reason, when you look at the facts. Way back in 2020, the announcement of Crimson Desert saw a 400% increase in share price. One could argue causation vs correlation, but investors haven't been as bullish since then. However, with the proposed release of Crimson Desert next year, a recent uptick in revenue for Black Desert Online, and the hopes that these will work together to drive renewed interest, you can understand why they're pushing hard.

The entire Heidel Ball stream can be viewed below, but I'll summarize it for those who want the high notes. Let's start with the technical first.

A PlayStation 5 Version of Black Desert Online is Coming

Let's not beat around the bush about Black Desert Online's inability to take advantage of the PS5 fully. Following the Calpheon Ball last winter, a version coming wasn't a secret, but Pearl Abyss revealed some more concrete information.

No concrete date has been given as to its launch, but what was said is that it will feature improved graphics, ranging from enhanced effects and textures to an increased draw distance, a better frame rate, improved loading times, and more. There will be a test before the end of this year.

Hardcore Servers - for the PVP Lovers

One would honestly think PVP should appeal to me. I like skill-based games, and I hate all of you humans. Every single one of you. Especially you. Still, I'm not a fan of player-vs-player combat, not in an MMORPG anyway. I'm very much a play-a-story and explore-a-world, in my own way and pace, kind of guy. Some arsehole chasing me across a field before catching me and then shoving their dagger up my sphincter does not a good experience make.

I'm saying this partly because Black Desert Online brings something genuinely interesting with Hardcore Servers. Please make no mistake: these are for those who want a PVP experience. Starting on the hardcore server, you'll be given a level 60 character with equipment starting at 230ap and 260dp, which can be enhanced. PVP is always on. You can't chat, you can't form parties, and when you die, you're sent to jail.

You get out of jail by gaining rest points or by fighting others in jail. I'm essentially looking at the jail as a mini-version of The Hunger Games, in a larger version of The Hunger Games, all done in the style of Black Desert Online. May the odds ever be in your favor.

Of course, the PS5 version and Hardcore server are more than just technical, which brings us to the bulk of updates.

Introducing the Dosa - the 28th Class

Twenty-eight classes. That isn't a small number; many MMOs never have such a wide range. Part of this is the enormous amount of balancing any new class requires. Wielding a sword and a pipe, the Dosa is arguably one of the most ostentatious of the game's characters, which is saying something.

Playing Black Desert Online as the Dosa will have you attacking enemies with a flurry of slashes from your Hwando sword. So far, so simple. Only here, you have a pipe. The Gombangdae (Asian) smoking pipe here is unique, allowing you to summon spectral allies and other abilities from its smoke. From Archers and Spearmen, which will attack your enemies, to what appears like AoE abilities to negatively affect those around you.

If there's anything to say, it looks impressive from the trailer. The Dosa's story links closely to the upcoming expansion, which I'll cover shortly. Long story short, he comes from a noble family accused of treason, though he managed to escape. From stealing food on the streets, he encountered the master of the "Sangdo School" and became her disciple. All of this takes place in the location of the main update.

Black Desert Online: Land of the Morning Light - Seoul

Pearl Abyss is fond of recreating locations, as they have created Heidel out of Beynac-et-Cazenac. For the next update, they're going to Seoul. Having worked with the South Korean Cultural Heritage Administration, they have recreated Gyeongbokgung Palace using drones, LIDAR, and other sources.

Following the previous expansion, Land of the Morning Light, based on South Korea, it made sense that Black Desert Online would take you to the capital. Of course, it's Pearl Abyss' version of the capital, featuring eight new bosses as part of the eight Korean tales it will tell us. With new five-player bosses and benefits to guilds, the team hopes the new content will help bring guilds closer together.

New primordial-grade Sovereign weapons will be introduced to reward your progress in Seoul. These will have their enhancement levels, later enhancements giving visual effects and being customizable, with up to five different effects to make that weapon your own. You will require at least one PEN Blackstar Weapon to gain your Sovereign weapon.

Rounding out this is Palace Management. Once you've completed the story, you can utilize a management system the developers say is not too dissimilar to a simulation game. Naturally, that piques my interest. With the Palace Management mode, you can utilize several production nodes that can increase in level. These work into a system that allows automated processing and trade, eventually leaving you only needing to sell the finished goods. It may not be a get-rich-quick scheme, but Pearl Abyss says it will offer a valuable income stream.

Black Desert Online: Chapter 2 - Into the Past

Probably the biggest news will be what's coming later. Ten years in, Black Desert Online is now at the end of its first chapter, so Pearl Abyss has started dropping some information on Chapter 2.

The first things to come will be a trip to Everfrost and then to the Demon Land. Following on from the Mountain of Eternal Winter expansion and quest line, you'll venture to the Everfrost mountains and find a massive dungeon with one hundred floors to fight through, each with increasing difficulty. Pearl Abyss promises that this, in particular, will promise a lot for those interested in the lore.

Then there is the Demon Land, which we have been told is designed to be one huge fortress. This will mark the end of Chapter One, and it's said that it will push you and your characters to the limit. Following this trip to the Demon Land will bring Black Desert Online's biggest update as it moves to Chapter Two. It's a trip into the past.

With the same world, but different, you will take a trip thousands of years into the past. What is desert now used to be lush. The world you know is different, and part of this exploration into the past will be to see where the Black Spirit originated from, and you may even get to change the future. Little more has been revealed regarding Chapter Two, but for those interested in the world and lore, it's likely an exciting trip.

item.title: The Acolyte can and should indulge in the Star Wars sequel trilogyâs Knights of Ren lore
item.content:encoded:
https://www.polygon.com/star-wars/24186170/acolyte-master-sith-knights-of-ren

Ever since George Lucas claimed the âechoesâ between his original and prequel Star Wars trilogies were âpoetry,â the mega-franchise has faced criticism of trapping characters in an everything-is-connected universe. When Kid Anakin is building C-3PO and Boba Fettâs dad is the base DNA for the Stormtroopers, Star Warsâ poetry suddenly looked more like Mad Libs than William Blake.

True to form, Lucasfilmâs newest series, The Acolyte, is forming similar echoes (hey, a show about twins!) and Easter eggs (turns out folks have a lot of strong feelings about Ki-Adi-Mundi). But its 100-year distance from known Skywalker Saga storytelling feels like expansion, the way history should. George R.R. Martin gets the approach â look at House of the Dragon â and The Acolyte creator Leslye Headland, mining the High Republic era, comes closer than most of her Star Wars contemporaries.

In episode 5, âNight,â Headland and The Acolyteâs writing team make a direct connection to a Big Star Wars thing, with the potential for an even loftier end goal: an embrace of sequel-trilogy lore. At least, I hope it is, because I am here for the Knights of Ren.

[Ed. note: This post contains major spoilers for The Acolyte episode 5.]

Picking up where episode 4, âDay,â left off, âNightâ is wall-to-wall lightsaber action as the Master slices his way through Jedi adversaries, and Mae and Osha deal with their shit. A face off with Jecki Lon (Dafne Keen) finally takes the Masterâs metal face... off... for the showâs big reveal: Itâs been Qimir, a so-called smuggler who turns out to be a wannabe Sith Master who hoped Mae was his ticket to the big time.

When Sol asks him what he wants his answer is simple, if nebulous: âFreedom. The freedom to wield my power the way I like without having to answer to Jedi like you. I want a pupil, an acolyte. But this one went back on our deal.â

Star Wars fandom went into a meltdown after âDay,â when the aforementioned Ki-Adi-Mundi popped up at the Jedi morning meeting to discuss what to do about the Master and Mae. A faction of vocal fans jumped to the conclusion that the Master must be Sith, and that The Acolyte invalidated Ki-Adi-Mundiâs assertion in The Phantom Menace that âthe Sith have been extinct for a millennium.â In theory, if Ki-Adi-Mundi and the High Republic Jedi (including Yoda) encountered a Sith back in the day, then Ki-Adi-Mundi is either a big fat liar in The Phantom Menace or The Acolyte broke canon. Or maybe the Master isnât Sith?

âNightâ does little to quell the fears of Ki-Adi-Mundi stans. When Sol has a chance to question the Master (emitting indie sleaze energy via actor Manny Jacinto), he comes up short. âI have no name,â the Master tells Sol, âbut a Jedi like you might call me Sith.â

Thatâs an open-and-shut case for people who think the remaining three episodes of The Acolyte will offer zero dramatic turns or greater reveals. But the Masterâs use of âmightâ is doing a lot of work for me, as well as his desperate attempt to find an acolyte. Iâm surprised more of the upset Star Wars fans arenât picking up what Jacinto is putting down in the scene: coming off like an extremely disgruntled fanboy.

In the final scene of âNight,â the Master utters some poetic parting words for the smacked-down Osha. Behind him, composer Michael Abels creates another connection to Star Wars history by quoting John Williamsâ Kylo Ren theme from The Force Awakens. This feels extremely telling â as a student of the genetically engineered Force-user Snoke (the sequels were a wild time!) who eventually led the Knights of Ren, Kylo was never a true Sith, just an enthusiast with Darth Vader memorabilia in his bedroom. Abels, nodding to Kylo through music, shades the Master with a similar gray; he might want Sol to refer to him as a Sith, but would a man of integrity like Ki-Adi-Mundi dignify him as such? Or is it more an eager Force-user manifesting his dream role?

The blurriness has brought me to my most fan-theorizing moment of The Acolyte, and a bit of my own wishful thinking: The Master might be a founder of the Knights of Ren, previously seen in the sequel trilogy.

On top of the overt nod to Kylo, the design of the Master in The Acolyte is leaning way further into the Knights of Ren than anything in the Sith wardrobe. While the movies offered little in the way of explanation for the Knights of Ren, save for a passing mention by Snoke in The Force Awakens and their bits of action in The Rise of Skywalker, auxiliary Star Wars materials have carved out plenty of foundational canon in true Star Wars fashion. As depicted in the Rise of Kylo Ren comics (written by Charles Soule, who also happens to be an engineer of the High Republic era), the Knights were roided-out marauders who wielded the Force with abandon as they pillaged sites across the galaxy. Their vibe screams âwould own a Cybertruck.â

The Acolyte costume designer Jennifer Bryan told Polygon that Donnie Darko was a major inspiration for the creepy, toothed-smile look of the Masterâs helmet, but when I saw him bust out his lightsaber moves in âNight,â muscled arms jabbing from under a flowing robe, I immediately pictured the leader of the Knights of Ren from the New Republic era. I could definitely see the Master running with [checks notes] âVicrul, the Reaper of the Fallenâ and other Knights of Ren with totally chill nicknames.

In 2022âs Star Wars: Crimson Reign, Charles Soule again expands the mythology of the Knights of Ren. The comic book series focuses on Qiâra, from Solo (who has become unexpectedly vital to Star Wars lore?), and the attempt destabilize the growing Empire. Part of Qiâraâs plan? Hiring the Knights of Ren to pull off a heist at Vaderâs castle on Mustafar. The relevant but almost throwaway line in the action-forward book is that the Knights of Ren have existed for centuries â and at some point fell from grace.

The Master may very well be the first step forward for a new age of Sith, and the Star Wars timeline continues to make less and less sense. But even as someone bristled over The Rise of Skywalkerâs all-too-neat Palpatine connections and the Exquisite Corpse exercise of the sequel trilogy, I would be eager to see Headland thread the Knights of Ren into broader Star Wars context.

The intrigue of the original Star Wars movies was that everything we see, even in a flash, has history behind it. Thereâs danger in carving out the backstory of characters like the Knights of Ren, basically window dressing with legs, but as Soule proved out in the comics, they do play an essential role in Kyloâs (underbaked) journey to the Dark Side and the spectrum of Force use in the galaxy. The High Republic readers know there are already established marauders in this era â see: Marchion Ro and the vicious Nihil â but if Headland wants to make the Star Wars universe more cohesive, more lived-in, sidestepping the obvious reveal of a new Sith for something more complicated would be a delightful twist for The Acolyte. The âacolyteâ of the title could be Mae or Osha, but as it stands after episode 5, the Master himself might fit the description, a devotee of the Dark Side who... just hasnât invented the Knights of Ren yet.
